item.title: San Antonio Medical Malpractice Attorney
item.description: Life in San Antonio, Texas, thrives with vibrant neighborhoods and exceptional medical facilities catering to the community's health needs. Despite the city's friendly nature, accidents do happen, and medical malpractice cases can leave individuals and families in distress. If you or your loved one have suffered harm due to medical negligence, rest assured that you have the right to seek just compensation under Texas law. Understanding Medical Malpractice in San Antonio In unfortunate circumstances, medical errors can lead to physical or psychological harm to innocent patients.

item.title: Patient dies from nursing home fall despite documented high risk
item.description: A physician friend of mine recently commented on social media that, “I’m old enough to remember when surgeons would take patients to the OR [operating room] for appys [appendix removal surgery] or cholecystitis [gallbladder inflammation] based on the physical exam and history. I still love those old school surgeons.” Her comment got me thinking about how old school medical care is different than whatâ€™s touted as improved care today. item.title: Baptist Medical Center San Antonio medical malpractice lawyer/attorney
item.description: As a Houston, Texas medical malpractice attorney, I handle medical negligence and wrongful death cases throughout the State of Texas, including the San Antonio area. According to the American Hospital Directory, this hospital has 1,487 beds and a total patient revenue exceeding $6.6 billion. item.title: What to do when your doctor downplays your symptoms
item.description: A new client recently called our office about poor health care he received at a primary care clinic in San Antonio. The man went to see his primary care provider because of ear pain that radiated down into his jaw. Strangely, the physician did not examine or look into the patient’s ear but instead quickly concluded that he had arthritis. Over the course of the next two months, the pain did not resolve so he returned to the primary care clinic on two more occasions.
